Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: 2016-2019 Development of the Askaryan Radio Array Ultra-High Energy Neutrino Detector at the South Pole
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ultra-high-energy neutrinos are unique astrophysical messengers that interact weakly with intervening matter and can therefore be used to probe the distant universe. A small but theoretically observable flux of these ultra-high-energy neutrinos is expected to be produced by the interaction between high-energy "cosmic ray" charged particles and cosmic microwave background photons as the cosmic rays travel through the Universe. Observing these cosmogenic neutrinos would allow physicists to begin to study physics at energies beyond the standard models. The large volume of radio transparent ice covering the geographic South Pole in Antarctica has hosted several pioneering efforts to detect these high energies neutrinos using a radio Cherenkov "Askaryan effect." The Askaryan effect describes the process by which ultra-high-energy neutrinos traversing the dense polar ice generate observable radio waves. The Askaryan Radio Array (ARA), located at the South Pole Station, was designed to exploit this phenomenon to first detect and ultimately study these ultra-high-energy neutrinos. This award provides funding to deploy two more ARA stations to the existing suite of three stations, and to continue observations. The award will support the involvement of students, including undergraduate students, who will be engaged in on-site activities at the South Pole. It will also support outreach efforts including activities with QuarkNet.

ARA is designed to be implemented in phases. During the initial phase the ARA project deployed a testbed and three full stations that used equipment designed and built for the co-located IceCube Neutrino Observatory. With this award the project will deploy two more stations and continue observations with all stations to demonstrate the technology, accumulate knowledge about radio frequency properties of the upper layers of the ice sheet at South Pole, and develop reliable hardware and software for deployable in-ice stations in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the project term January 1, 2018 -> December 31, 2018, the KU group continued to develop it's Antarctic research program along four broad lines of inquiry:

1) Radioglaciological studies with the ARA experiment. Here, we have measured all three portions of the complex dielectric permittivity: The real part of the permittivity dictates ray refraction through the ice, and therefore the degree to which neutrino source vertices may be `shadowed'. The real component is measured using the time difference measured for rays traveling along direct ("D") vs. refracted ("R") paths from an in-ice source point; owing to the increasing density with depth (and therefore, increasing refractive index with depth), two propagation solutions are, in general, allowed. The imaginary part of the permittivity dictates signal absorption through the ice and therefore the visibility to a putative neutrino interaction point (in the unshadowed region). The tensorial nature of the permittivity results in propagation velocity asymmetries for Vertically, vs. Horizontally polarized signal, aka, birefringence. This effort culminated in an Astropart. Phys. Journal article, published at the end of 2018.

2) Development of inexpensive, high-amplitude (~5 kV), short-duration (~10 ns) signal generators. Our work over the last few years has primarily concentrated on use of piezo-electric technology to generate high-voltage signals. This approach was successfully used for the tests done using a transmitter in the SPICE (South Pole Ice Core Experiment) ice hole on January 8, 2018, and again, during the last week of December, 2018. Within the last year, we have expanded our work to develop high-voltage pulsers using either a DC->DC converter or a transistor array avalanche; unlike the piezo, both of these transmitters can be tied to a gps pps trigger, facilitating recognition of such events in the ARA data sample. Our pulsers have, by now, been used for the ARA, ARIANNA and also ANITA experiments.

3) Studies of radio-frequency signals emitted via the geosynchrotron process. Although the ANITA and ARIANNA experiments have recorded O(100) and O(1000) such triggers, respectively, in their data sets, thus far, ARA has not performed a dedicated search for ultra-high energy hadronic cosmic rays via their radio emissions. Following the heritage of the (never-funded) RASTA experiment, the KU group has recently embarked on a targeted study of such cosmic ray signatures, which will form the basis of graduate student Latif's thesis.

4) Investigations into new techniques for cosmic-ray detection. Since 2011, the KU group have been involved in tests designed to quantify the feasibility of radar detection of cosmic rays, using reflections from the ionization trail (plasma) left in the wake of a cosmic-ray collision with terrestrial matter. Although initial studies searching for in-air reflections were unsuccessful, recent results from testbeam studies indicate that such a technique may, indeed, be a promising strategy for measuring neutrino-ice collisions.
